greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(0) = 0, a(1) = 1, a(2*n) = 2*a(n), a(2*n+1) = a(n) XOR a(n+1).
comment: a(n) is the n-th Stern polynomial (cf. A260443, A125184) evaluated at X = 2 over the field GF(2).
For n >= 1, a(n) gives the index of the row where n occurs in array A277710.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..16384
formula: A000035(a(n)) = A000035(n). [Preserves the parity of n.]
A001511(a(n)) = A001511(n) = A055396(A277330(n)). [In general, the 2-adic valuation of n is preserved.]
The following two identities are so far unproved:
example: In this example, binary numbers are given zero-padded to four bits.
mathematica: recurXOR[0] = 0; recurXOR[1] = 1; recurXOR[n_] := recurXOR[n] = If[EvenQ[n], 2recurXOR[n/2], BitXor[recurXOR[(n - 1)/2 + 1], recurXOR[(n - 1)/2]]]; Table[recurXOR[n], {n, 0, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 23 2016 *)
program: ;; Where A003987bi computes bitwise-XOR as in A003987.
def a(n): return n if n<2 else 2*a(n//2) if n%2==0 else a((n - 1)//2)^a((n + 1)//2)
print([a(n) for n in range(51)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Jul 27 2017
xref: Cf. A277701, A277712, A277713 (positions of 1's, 2's and 3's in this sequence).
Cf. A277711 (position of the first occurrence of each n in this sequence).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 10 2015
